body_text.text: mainly consists of two stages: (1) creating reasonable networks for the interested 19 healthcare service systems and (2) identifying the influential nodes in the created 20 networks. 21 Much research has been conducted to abstract healthcare systems as networks, 22 and most of this research has focused on creating "patient-sharing networks" based both deliver care to the same patient and examined the approaches to conceptual-43 izing, measuring, and analyzing provider patient-sharing networks. 44 There are typically two procedures in identifying influential nodes in the cre-45 ated networks: (1) ranking nodes according to nodal influence measure metrics, 46 such as degree centrality [11] , clustering coefficients [12] , H-Index [13, 14] , and 47 k-shell [15, 16] ; and (2) evaluating the influence of top-ranked nodes by compar- 48 ing the structures and functions before and after removing a certain percentage of 49 top-ranked nodes. 50 Currently, many algorithms have been proposed for identifying influential nodes. In this paper, we propose a network-based method with privacy-preserving The novelty of the proposed method can be explained as follows. As mentioned 79 above, most of the related research is based on patient-sharing networks, which 80 are created according to electronic medical claims, focusing on the sharing of pa-81 tient information between providers. The advantage of creating patient-sharing 82 networks is that they are quite precise. However, the data of electronic medical 83 claims are personal and private [32, 33] , and the data are generally not directly 84 available to the public. Healthcare organizations need to consider regulations and 85 rules of privacy in regard to patient information. Researchers need to deal with 86 personal privacy information carefully before creating the required patient-sharing 87 network.

In contrast, our study is based on a patient-sharing network rather than the 89 provider-interacting network. In the proposed method, the provider-interacting net-90 work joined by healthcare providers can be roughly created according to the loca-91 tion and available types of healthcare service, without the need for personal, private 92 electronic medical claims data. We only utilize the relationships between providers 93 to identify influential providers, thus protecting the privacy of patients. Most im-
The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows.
(1) We construct a provider-interacting network by employing publicly avail-103 able information on locations and types of healthcare services of providers.
(2) We rank the influential nodes of the created provider-interacting networks 105 using four local metrics.
(3) We evaluate the impact of the top-ranked influential nodes in the provider-107 interacting network using three indicators.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the details 109 of the proposed network-based method for identifying the influential provider of 110 healthcare service in the provider-interacting network. Section 3 presents the ap-

In this section, we will first introduce the data source and then describe the 116 details of the proposed network-based method. (1) npi -NPI for the performing provider on the claim. The provider's NPI is 124 the numeric identifier registered in the NPPES. Each provider has a unique NPI.
(2) nppes provider zip -The provider's ZIP code.
(3) hcpcs code -Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) 127 code used to identify the specific medical service provided.

The availability of the obtained datasets is as follows. In this paper, we propose a network-based method with privacy-preserving for 134 identifying influential providers in large healthcare service systems. The proposed 135 network-based method is composed of three main procedures.

The first procedure is the construction of the network, which uses the ZIP code 137 and HCPCS code of the providers to build the provider-interacting networks. The 138 key step in this procedure is to set a threshold value for the location of the neigh-139 boring providers, specify that providers within the threshold range can generate the 140 connection relationship, and add weights to the edges according to the similarity 141 of the types of medical services provided.

The second procedure is to rank influential nodes. The ranking of the nodes in 143 the generated provider-interacting network is conducted in parallel on the basis of 144 four nodal influence metrics, including the DC, CB, CC, and H-Index.
The third procedure is to evaluate the impact of the identified influential nodes.

By removing a certain proportion of the top-ranked nodes, the impact on the three 147 indicators of the network is evaluated, including the maximum connectivity co-effectiveness of the influential nodes ranking algorithm.

(2) HCPCS code similarity 186 The HCPCS is divided into two principal subsystems, referred to as level I and there is descriptive terminology that identifies a category of similar items.

In this paper, we specify that the set of HCPCS codes for medical services 194 provided by node v i is represented by S i , and the set of HCPCS codes provided by 195 node v j is represented by S j . If two providers have the same HCPCS code, they 196 are considered potential neighbors, and the weight of the edge is k (Eq. (3)).

Fig. 9 (a) and Fig. 9 (b) show that when removal ratios reach 0.5% ∼ 1%, us-441 ing the metric DC to remove the top-ranked nodes leads to the largest decline in the 442 maximum connectivity coefficient and network efficiency, followed by the metrics 443 CB and H-Index. The metric CC leads to a slight decrease in the maximum con-444 nectivity coefficient and network efficiency, which is almost unchanged. In Fig. 9 445 (c), the metrics CC and H-Index reduce the susceptibility by a small margin, which 446 is almost unchanged, while the metric CB reduces the maximum connectivity co-447 efficient and network efficiency by the largest margin, followed by the metric DC.

FIGREF0.text: 23 on electronic medical claims [4]. For example, Pollack et al [5] first created patient-24 sharing networks among physicians using medical claims data and then investi-25 gated care coordination and costs of care. Ong et al [6] created a patient-sharing 26 network using commercial healthcare claims spanning the years 2008 through 27 2011 and elucidated the effect of professional relationships among providers on 28 multiple-provider prescriptions of benzodiazepines. 29 Moreover, using Medicare Part B claims data, Moen et al [7] first constructed 30 a network of physicians who care for patients with cardiovascular disease based 31 on patient-sharing relationships and then analyzed a case study of physicians' ad-32 herence to clinical guidelines for the prevention of sudden cardiac death. Using a 33 dataset consisting of 1,306 physicians who practiced within the Chicago hospital 34 referral region in 2016 and who collectively had 12,091 patient-sharing ties, Linde 35 [8] created a patient-sharing network and examined the degree to which hospital 36 affiliation drives physicians' sharing of Medicare patients. 37 In addition, Landon et al [9] identified patient-sharing networks in which physi-38 cians share patients, information, and behaviors and presented a social network 39 analysis of Medicare administrative data from 2006 to 2010 in 51 hospital referral 40 regions. Similarly, DuGoff et al [10] constructed patient-sharing networks using 41 administrative data in which pairs of physicians are considered connected if they 42

FIGREF1.text: Most of the identification algorithms are designed for online social networks [17, 52 18, 19]. In these identifications, some influence measures, such as degree central-53 ity [11], betweenness centrality [20], closeness centrality [21], and Katz centrality 54 [22], are highly dependent on the topological structure of the network. Moreover, 55 Xiao et al [12] used company behaviors and clustering coefficient to rank nodes. 56 Lu et al [13] adopted the H-Index [14] to identify vital nodes. Kitsak et al. [23] 57proposed the theory of k-shell decomposition to identify influential nodes.58 In addition, in the development of search engines, there are also important 59 and famous algorithms for ranking nodes, such as PageRank [24], HITs [25], and 60 LeaderRank [26]. These ranking algorithms have been excellently investigated and 61 summarized in several reviews [27, 20]. The node ranking and influential nodes 62 identification methods have their own advantages and disadvantages. Users can 63 employ suitable metrics and develop algorithms in their specific applications.

Ranking of the Influential Nodes 204 In network science, one of the most important research areas is how to rank 205 influential nodes in a complex network [38]. It is interesting to rank nodes when 206 there are a massive number of nodes and find the vital providers that have a strong 207 impact on the function and efficiency of the whole network. For example, it is 208 possible to replace the missing vital nodes in a timely manner to protect the network 209 from paralysis and maintain the stability of the medical system [39].210 Moreover, Gao et al [40] proposed a local structural centrality measure to rank 211 the spreading ability of nodes in the network. Zhao et al [41] proposed the IM-LPA 212 algorithm to solve the influence maximization problem in social networks with 213 a community structure. Mo et al [42] proposed a new comprehensive centrality 214 measure based on Dempster-Shafer evidence theory. algorithms can be roughly divided into two categories: one is based 216 on local nodal influence metrics such as the degree centrality, and the other is based 217 on global metrics such as the betweenness centrality, closeness centrality, and k-218 shell metrics [43]. 219 In this paper, after considering the ranking metrics that are relatively suit-220 able for undirected weighted provider-interacting networks, four nodal influential 221 metrics are used to rank nodes, including (1) the degree centrality [11] , measured by the degree of a node, which can directly reflect the possi-226 bility of the node having direct contact with other nodes in the network (Eq. indicates the DC of node v i and K i indicates the degree of node v i . To 228 reflect the function of weighted edges, we specify how many HCPCS codes are 229 the same between nodes v i and v j , and how many connecting edges are there be-230 tween nodes v i and v j . When calculating the DC of node v i , the number of added 231 connected edges can be equivalent to the number of increased neighbors. For a 232network where node v i has n connected edges, the maximum degree of a node is 233 n−1. After the node is divided by n−1 for normalization, there is 0 ≤ DC i ≤ 1.234The larger the value is, the stronger the centrality of the nodes is [37].235(2) Companion Behaviors (CB)236    The local metric CB was originally proposed byMei et al [12]  and is based on 237 the calculation of Jaccard Coefficients (JCs) of edges. The JC reflects the differ-238 ence between the neighbors of two nodes, that is, the relationship strength of two

FIGREF16.text: of the H-Index proposed by J.E. Hirsch [14] is as follows. All268 n papers published by an author are sorted in descending order by the size of the 269 citation frequency. If and only if the citation frequency of each paper in the first h 270 papers is at least h and the citation frequency of the h+1 paper in the first h papers 271 is less than h+1, then value h is defined as the H-Index of the author. If F i is set as 272 the citation frequency of article i, the expression of the H-Index can be written as 273 in Eq. (8).274 H = max(i), F i ≥ i (8) Similarly, a node has an H-Index h if h of its neighbors have a degree of at 275 least h [12].276 2.3.3. Impact Evaluation of the Identified Influential Nodes 277 There are two typical categories of indicators to evaluate the effectiveness of 278 influential node ranking algorithms: (1) the propagation dynamics of the network 279 and (2) the resilience (also called the robustness) of the network [30]. The re-280 silience is a system's ability to adjust its activity to retain its basic functionality 281 when errors, failures, and environmental changes occur [45]. 282 The research on network resilience due to external damage such attacks has 283 drawn much attention in network science [46]. In general, there are two kinds 284 of attacks on complex networks: random attacks and selective attacks. Random 285 attacks mean that nodes are randomly removed with a certain probability, while 286 selective attacks mean that nodes or edges are selectively deleted in a certain way 287 [47]. Research on the structural robustness of network nodes subjected to random 288 failures or malicious attacks has been widely studied [28]. the concept of network resilience, in this paper, we employ three in-290 dicators, including the maximum connectivity coefficient, network efficiency, and 291 susceptibility, to quantify the impact of selective removal of top-ranked influential 292 nodes on the network structure and function. We abstract this situation as node 293 deletion due to the influential provider's own reasons (such as retirement or resig-294 nation) or other external factors. The results can be examined in two aspects: (a) 295 the connectivity of the network has been damaged; and (b) the efficiency of the net-296 work has declined, resulting in the network not meeting the business requirements. Maximum connectivity coefficient 298 The maximum connectivity coefficient of a network can be calculated by first 299 ranking the nodes according to the nodal influence metrics from the largest to the 300 smallest and then observing the impact of removing a part of the nodes on the giant 301 connected component (Eq. (9)). 302 G = R/N (9) where N represents the total number of nodes in the network and R represents the 303 giant connected component. The smaller the scale of the giant connected compo-304

FIGREF17.text: remove nodes and all their corresponding edges in the network, some paths in310 the network are interrupted, resulting in the shortest path between some nodes 311 becoming larger, and then the average path length of the whole network increases, 312 affecting network connectivity [30].

FIGREF19.text: The giant connected component decreases with an increase in the number of 325 removed nodes and vanishes when a critical proportion p c of nodes is removed 326 [27]. To find the accurate p c value, the susceptibility S of the network is calculated 327 before and after removing a certain number of nodes (Eq. (12)). s is the number of components of size s, n is the size of the whole network 329 and R represents the giant connected component. 330 In general, there is a peak value of S at the critical proportion p c of network 331 collapses. If the network experiences multiple collapses during selective node dele-332 tion, there are multiple peaks, and the p c value is determined by the highest one.

FIGREF20.text: according to the objective function on network connectivity, the smaller 334 the value of p c is, the better the sorting algorithm. 335 2.4. Implementation Details of the Proposed Method336

As has been described several times, there are three 339 main procedures in the proposed method: (1) constructing the provider-interacting 340 network, (2) ranking the influential nodes in the generated provider-interacting net-341 work, and (3) evaluating the impact of top-ranked influential nodes. In this paper, we directly employ the source 399 code presented in our previous work [12] to rank the influential nodes. Much more 400 implementation detail is provided in reference [12].

FIGREF30.text: The influence of removing the top nodes with different proportions on the (a) maximum connectivity coefficient, (b) network efficiency, and (obvious advantage of the proposed method is that it does not require 455 the information of personally private medical claims.456 As mentioned above, patient-sharing networks are created according to elec-457 tronic medical claims, and the advantage of creating patient-sharing networks is 458 that they are quite precise. However, the data of electronic medical claims are per-459 sonal and private [32, 33]. Personally private information needs to be carefully 460 addressed before creating the required patient-sharing networks [50, 51]. 461 In contrast, in the proposed method, the provider-interacting network joined by 462 healthcare providers can be roughly created according to the location and the avail-463 able types of healthcare services, without the need for personally private electronic 464 medical claims. For example, the data of the location and the provided types of 465 healthcare service are publicly available at the U.S. Centers for Medicare & Med-466 icaid Services (https://www.cms.gov/). This is the main advantage of the 467 proposed method.

FIGREF31.text: Shortcomings of the Proposed Method 469 One of the essential ideas behind the proposed method is the construction of 470 the provider-interacting network, rather than the commonly used patient-sharing 471 networks. Those patient-sharing networks are typically constructed based on med-472 ical claims data. Medical claims are usually quite accurate, and the patient-sharing 473 network is also quite accurate in reflecting the relationships between providers. 474 Compared with those patient-sharing networks constructed based on medical 475 claims data, the provider-interacting network is generated according to the loca-476 tion and available healthcare service of the providers, more specifically, according 477 29 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f to the ZIP codes and HCPCS codes of the providers. In the proposed method, 478 several nearby providers located within a certain distance who provide the same 479 HCPCS codes are linked and considered neighbors in the provider-interacting net-480 work.

FIGREF32.text: China, during the period of epidemic prevention, the demand for front-line 503 30 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f medical staff, disinfection materials, protective equipment and emergency supplies 504 in the respiratory tract infection department increased dramatically. In contrast, 505 many patients with other diseases went to the hospital as little as possible; thus, 506 the investment in diagnosis and treatment in other departments of the hospital de-507 creased, and the required medical resources (e.g., the labor and material resources) 508 decreased accordingly. 509 It is quite meaningful to employ the proposed method in this paper to build a 510 network of hospital providers, identify the important providers remaining to main-511 tain the normal operation of local medical services, and transfer other redundant 512 providers and available medical materials to support areas heavily affected by the 513 epidemic. In this way, the proposed method can not only effectively ensure that 514 local hospitals maintain their capability to provide healthcare services but can also 515 reasonably distribute medical resources, which plays an important role in epidemic 516 prevention. Moreover, more attention needs to be paid to strengthening the distri-517 bution of personnel and facilities in district and community level medical institu-518 tions. According to urban planning, the method in this paper ensures that public 519 medical resources can flow between different levels corresponding to different ge-520 ographical units and can be transferred at the grassroots level to establish a resilient 521 and hierarchical healthcare service system.

More-525 over, in the proposed method, several nearby providers located within a certain 526 distance who provide the same HCPCS codes are linked. This procedure may 527

FIGREF34.text: future, we will generate a nationwide provider-interacting network for further 530 research and optimize the selection of a proper distance threshold.531 Moreover, with significant advances in communication technologies, an era 532 of Internet of Things (IoT) appears [58, 59]. A large amount of IoT data can be 533 collected in various ways [60, 61] which may be used to generate networks for 534 healthcare service systems. Identifying influential providers in those generated 535 network-based systems can also help optimize and distribute the healthcare service536

FIGREF35.text: important step towards optimizing the use of available healthcare resources and 540 ensuring the more efficient delivery of matched healthcare services. In this pa-541 per, we proposed a network-based method with privacy-preserving for identifying 542 influential providers in large healthcare service systems. First, we constructed a 543 provider-interacting network by employing the publicly available information on 544 the locations and types of healthcare service of providers. Second, we ranked the 545 nodes in the generated provider-interacting network on the basis of four nodal in-546 fluence metrics. Third, we evaluated the impact of those top-ranked influential 547 nodes in the provider-interacting network by comparing three network indicators. 548 The proposed method is demonstrated by employing the dataset of Physician and 549 Other Supplier Data CY 2017, and can be applied to other similar datasets to help 550 make decisions for healthcare system management, such as the optimization of 551 healthcare resources in the response to public health emergencies. 552 This research was jointly supported by the National Natural Science Founda-554 tion of China (Grant Numbers: 11602235), and the Fundamental Research Funds 555 for China Central Universities (Grant Numbers: 2652018091, 2652018107, and 556 2652018109). The proposed method is finally demonstrated by employing Physician and Other Supplier Data CY 2017 [31] and can be applied to other similar datasets to help make healthcare system management decisions, such as the optimization of healthcare resources.

TABREF7.text: This procedure may not be accurate because it is not able to determine the best distance threshold for selecting neighboring providers. In fact, the distance threshold is specified. Thus, the generation of the provider-interacting network is not as accurate as that of the patient-sharing network.The proposed method can be applied to help make decisions for healthcare sys-tems management, such as the optimization of healthcare resources in the response to public health emergencies [52]. For example, since mid-December 2019, coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been spreading from Wuhan, China. The epidemic quickly disseminated from Wuhan, and as of 12 February 2020, 45,179 cases have been confirmed in 25 countries, including 1,116 deaths [53]. As of March 1, 2020, it has spread to 58 other countries [54]. Recognizing the Wuhanfocused and nationwide outbreak responses in China, the WHO has encouraged countries with heavy air travel exchanges with Wuhan to take precautionary public health measures and, if there is an imported infection, to undertake activities that could lead to the elimination of the virus in human populations, as occurred during the 2003 SARS outbreak [55]. Rapid and effective collaboration betweenthe clinicians (e.g., the general practitioners attending the cases, emergency hotline clinicians, and infectious diseases specialists), the National Reference Centre and the regional and national health authorities has played a crucial role in the systemic capacity to quickly detect, isolate and investigate cases to implement adequate con-
